column1: East Java (Indonesian: Jawa Timur) is a province of Indonesia. It has a land border only with the province of Central Java to the west; the Java Sea and the Indian Ocean border its northern and southern coasts
column2: respectively
column3: while the narrow Bali Strait to the east separates Java from Bali. Located in eastern Java
column4: it also includes the island of Madura
column5: which is connected to Java by the longest bridge in Indonesia
column7: as well as the Kangean and Masalembu archipelagos located further east and north
column8: respectively. Its capital is Surabaya
column9: the second largest city in Indonesia
column10: a major industrial center and also a major business center. Banyuwangi is the largest regency in East Java and the largest on the island of Java.The province covers an area of 47
column15: 757 people residing in the East Java
column16: making it Indonesia's second-most-populous province; the latest official estimate (for mid 2019) is 39
column18: 800. East Java is inhabited by many different ethnic groups
column20: Madurese and Chinese. Most of the people in East Java adheres to Islam
column21: forming around 96% of the total population. Other religions are also worshipped
column23: which are mostly worshipped by Chinese Indonesians and immigrants from Eastern Indonesia and North Sumatra
column24: and also Hinduism which are mostly worshipped by the Tenggerese people in the Bromo Tengger Semeru National Park and the Balinese people inhabiting the easternmost part of the province bordering Bali. The Indonesian language is the official language of the province as well as the whole nation
column25: but Javanese and Madurese are the most frequently used language. Indonesian is only used for inter-ethnic communication and official purposes.

column1: The Dinoyo inscriptions found near the city of Malang are the oldest written sources in East Java
column2: dating from 760 CE. They tell of many political and cultural events in the Kingdom of Dinoyo. The name of Malang is thought to come from the name of a sacred building called Malangkuseswara. This name is contained in at least one inscription

column2: Ken Arok founded the Kingdom of Singhasari

column4: Ken Arok seized power in Tumapel (Kediri) from Tungul Ametung. Ken Arok dynasty's descendants became kings of Singhasari and Majapahit from the 13th until the 15th century.

column2: the Kingdom of Majapahit was founded. Its founder was Raden Wijaya. Majapahit reached its peak during the reign of Hayam Wuruk. He was accompanied by the mahapatih Gajah Mada. Together they managed to unite the vast territory under the name Dwipantara. Majaphit later developed to become one of the strongest empire in Southeast Asia.
the Bubat event occurred

column8: and was succeeded by Wikramawardhana. This resulted in the beginning of the decline of the Majapahit Empire. As the Majapahit Empire went into decline in the late 1300s

column1: The precise date when Islam enters Java remains unclear. This is due to the absence of a definite source regarding the arrival of Islam in Java. However
column2: according to some experts
column3: it is estimated that Islam entered Java around the 11th century with evidence of the tomb of Fatimah Binti Maimun in the village of Leran in Gresik Regency which dates from 475 AH (1085 AD). The tomb also shows that in the 11th century the North coast of Java had begun to be frequented by Arab traders from the Middle East. In addition

column8: which tells the story of the countries visited by him over the course of the Ming treasure voyages. He mentioned that at that time there were three different kind of people inhabiting Eastern Java: Arabs from the Middle-East

column22: until finally the da'wah entered and was carried out by the rulers of this island.

column1: The relationship between the Javanese and European colonial powers began in 1522
column2: with the signing of a treaty between the Sunda Kingdom and the Portuguese Empire in Malacca. After the failure of the treaty
column3: the Portuguese presence was then limited to Malacca in the Malay Peninsula and the Maluku Islands. An expedition under the leadership of the Dutch explorer Cornelis de Houtman consisting of four ships in 1596 became the beginning of Dutch presence in the island. At the end of the 18th century
column4: the Dutch had succeeded in expanding their influence on the Islamic sultanates in the interior of the island of Java.

column1: At the onset of the Napoleonic Wars
column2: the British conquered Java in 1811. Java later briefly became part of the British Empire
column3: with Sir Stamford Raffles as its Governor-General. In 1814
column4: Britain returned Java to the Netherlands as stipulated in the Anglo-Dutch Treaty of 1814.

column1: East Java is crossed by several national roads as primary arterial roads
column2: including the northern coastal national road or locally known as pantura road (Anyer-Jakarta-Surabaya-Banyuwangi)
column3: and inland national roads (Jakarta-Bandung-Yogyakarta-Surabaya). The expressway network in East Java covers the Surabaya-Gempol Toll Road; Gempol-Pandaan; Pandaan-Malang; Gempol-Pasuruan; and Pasuruan-Probolinggo which connects the northern and middle East Java regions with the southern and eastern salient (tapal kuda)
column4: the Surabaya-Gresik Toll Road that connects the middle and southern East Java to the north
column5: and the Surabaya-Mojokerto Toll Road; Mojokerto-Kertosono; Ngawi-Kertosono; and Solo-Ngawi which connects East Java with Central Java. Suramadu Bridge that crosses the Madura Strait connects Surabaya and Madura Island. In the near future
column6: the construction of the Probolinggo-Banyuwangi Toll Road will be realized
column7: which is the final segment of the Trans Java Toll Road
column8: the Krian-Legundi-Bunder-Manyar Toll Road that connects the industrial estates in the city of Surabaya; Sidoarjo Regency; and Gresik Regency
column9: as well as plans for the Gresik-Tuban Toll Road that connects East Java with cities on the northern coast of Java.

column1: Another important form of education that is available in most cities in East Java is the pesantren. This is a kind of socio-education organized by Islamic clerics

column1: East Java supports several regional media outlets. Local newspapers with provincial news reach their readers earlier than their competitors from Jakarta. In the spirit of "providing more news from around readers"
column2: most newspapers even issue municipal sections which are different among their distribution areas. More startups media also develop for younger generation.
one of the major newspaper groups in Indonesia

column1: Malang metropolitan region is a famous tourist destination in Indonesia with the City of Batu as its center.East Java has a number of interesting sights. One of the tourist icon is Mount Bromo in East Java
column2: which is inhabited by the Tengger tribe
column3: where the ceremony is held every year Kasada. In the mountainous region of Tengger also there is a waterfall that is Madakaripura which is the last hermitage Mahapatih Gajah Mada before serving in the kingdom of Majapahit. Madakaripura Waterfall has a height of about 200 meters
column4: which makes it the highest waterfall on the island of Java and the second highest in Indonesia. East Java also has some other mountainous tourist area of which is Malang Raya mountainous area known as the natural mountain tourist area that includes Malang and Batu. Tretes and Trawas mountainous areas
column5: are also known to have characteristics such as Puncak area in West Java province. Other natural attractions in East Java is the National Park (4 of 12 National Parks in Java) and Taman Safari Indonesia II in Prigen.

column1: East Java is also contained relics of history in the classical era. Trowulan sites in Mojokerto
column2: once the center of the Majapahit Kingdom
column3: there are dozens of temples and tombs of the kings of Majapahit. Other temples spread throughout much of East Java
column4: including Penataran temple in Blitar. In Madura
column5: Sumenep is the center of the kingdom of Madura
column8: and the tombs of the kings of Madura (Asta Tinggi Sumenep).

column1: East Java is known for its coastal scenery. On the south coast there is the Prigi Beach

column3: Popoh Beach in Tulungagung
column4: Ngliyep Beach
column5: and tourism areas such as the Jatim Park

column10: and the Watu Ulo Beach in Jember. East Java also has a beach that the waves is one of the best in the world
column11: namely the Plengkung Beach located in Banyuwangi. In addition there Kenjeran Beach in Surabaya
column12: and the White Sand Beach in Situbondo. Lake in East Java

column1: In the coastal area of the north there are a number of tombs of the saints
column2: which are places of pilgrimage for Muslims. Five of the nine walisongo are buried in East Java: Sunan Ampel in Surabaya
column3: Sunan Giri
column4: and Malik Ibrahim in Gresik
column5: Sunan Drajat in Paciran (Lamongan)
column7: Tuban. In the northern coastal region there are a number of caves
column8: including Maharani Cave in Lamongan and Tuban Akbar Cave and Cave Gong located in Pacitan. Other pilgrimage sites include the tomb of Indonesia's first president Sukarno
column9: in Blitar
column10: as well as the tomb of the fourth Indonesian president Abdurrahman Wahid

column1: Meru Betiri National Park – Between Jember and Banyuwangi districts
column2: this park covers 580 km2 (224 sq mi). Hard to get to
column3: it contains coastal rainforest and scenery and is home to abundant wildlife.

column1: Alas Purwo National Park – This 434 km2 (168 sq mi) park is formed by the Blambangan Peninsula (southeastern Java). Comprising mangrove
column2: savanna
column3: lowland monsoon forests and beaches
column4: the park's name means First Forest in Javanese. Javanese legend says that the earth first emerged from the ocean here.

column1: Baluran National Park – This 250 km2 (97 sq mi) national park is located in northeastern Java
column2: known as The Little Africa
column3: formerly extensive savanna has been largely replaced by Acacia.

column1: Bromo Tengger Semeru National Park – Located in East Java at the region of Probolinggo and Pasuruan
column2: 70 km (43 mi) from Surabaya the capital city of East Java province. Mount Bromo is one of the great hiking and trekking destinations for overseas tourists. The scenic view of Bromo also attracts hundreds of photo enthusiasts to see the views there.

column1: Some typical East Javanese dishes include Bakso Malang
column2: Rawon

column27: a staple food used to be a part of the population in Pacitan and Trenggalek. Tulungagung is famous for its lodho

column1: East Java is the province with the highest number of professional football clubs in Indonesia and also province with clubs in top division league. By 2019 season
column2: Indonesian First League clubs from East Java are Persela
column3: Madura United
column4: Arema
column5: and Persebaya. Arema and Persebaya are football clubs from East Java who have become top teams in Indonesia by repeatedly winning championships and national competitions and often as representatives of Indonesia in AFC Champions League and AFC Cup between clubs in Asia.

column1: East Java once hosted the National Sports Week (PON)
column2: namely PON VII in 1969
column3: and PON XV in 2000
column4: and became the overall champion of PON in 2000
column5: and 2008. Since 1996 the East Java Football Team always won medals gold was included in 2008
column6: and was recorded as the fourth gold medal received consecutively.

column1: East Java has several professional basketball clubs
column2: mainly in Surabaya. The famous basketball clubs namely CLS Knights Indonesia and Pacific Cesar Surabaya. East Java is also the venue for several bicycle racing events namely Tour de East Java and Tour de Ijen.
